div.p: THE EPITOME OF DIVINITY Poetically compos'd by way of Dialogue, for the more eaſie, and pleaſant learning and retaining of it in memory.
OR, A ſummary Abſtract of Divine Knowledge, as farre as is neceſſary to SALVATION.
Intended for the benefit of all, and eſpecially for the Education of Youth, in the Knowledge and Feare of God.
By WALTER FRANKE, Miniſter of Gods Word.
div.q: John 5. 39. Search the Scriptures, for in them ye have eternall life, and they are they which teſtifie of me.
div.p: LONDON, Printed by J. G. for Francis Eaglesfield, at the Marigold in St. Paul's Church-yard, 1655.

div.head: To the Right VVorſhipfull, and Vertuous Lady, the Lady ANNE BASSET; and to the like Vertuous and Religious Gentlewom • n, Mrs. Jane, and Mrs. Elizabeth Baſſet.
div.p:
HOnoured Ladies, I am not ignorant that ingratitude is a ſinne of an high nature, and none more baſe and monſtrous; leſt therefore I ſhould ſeeme to you, guilty of that crime, which I have alwaies in my heart ſo much abhorred; I have now taken an opportunity to expreſſe my thankfulneſſe, for the manifold favours and benefits, which (in the depth of my afflictions) I have received from you. And no other way have I really to expreſſe it, but by the dedication of this little Book to your Ladiſhips acceptance: which if you ſhall condeſcend to patronize, (as your former reſpects unto me, makes me confident you will) I ſhall rather increaſe, than any way leſsen
my engagements to you. The ſtructure of it being ſo ſmall and low, may in the eyes of ſome ſeem contemptible, in reſpect of thoſe large and faire buildings of like nature, that by others of farre richer endowments have been erected: yet as you have often ſeen the whole world deſcribed in a little Map, or the lively portraicture of a tall Man or Woman in a Shillings compaſse, ſo is here (although I muſt confeſſe for the manner, but rudely contrived) yet for the matter, the whole body of Divinity contained in a ſmall Epitome; which being ſo little and weake, as it hath the more need of ſuccour, ſo it may with the more facility from your Ladiſhips favour receive protection. I know you will take the paines often to peruſe it (becauſe I am well aſſured, that each of you doe ſpend ſome houres every day in Religious duties) and peruſing it, I doubt not but you will apply it, to the edification and adorning of your owne Soules, to Gods glory, and your owne eternall comfort: which that you may doe, and daily increaſe in the knowledge and grace of our Lord Jeſus Christ, ſhall be the prayer of

closer.signed: Your moſt obliged Servant in the Lord, Walter Franke.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
COurteous and well-diſpoſed Reader (if ſo thou art) it was the ſaying of him who (by the Spirit of God himſelfe) is ſaid to be a man after Gods owne heart, even David that great King, and ſweet ſinger of Iſrael; I have rejoyced in the way of thy teſtimonies above all riches, Pſal. 119. 14. And againe, Pſal. 19. 10. Th • y are more to be deſired than gold, yea, than much fine gold, ſweeter alſo than the Hony, or the Hony combe, with many ſuch exp • eſſions of like nature in the ſame Pſalme. And will you know the reaſon of this his tranſcendent eſteeme of them? you may then thus collect it. As in the whole viſible World, there is nothing of more excellency than Man, and in Man, nothing more excellent than the Soule, and in the Soule, nothing more excellent than the Underſtanding, and in the Underſtanding, nothing more excellent than Wiſdome; ſo moſt certain it is, that no Wiſdome that the Underſtanding is capable of, is ſo excellent as the Wiſdome from above, or the Knowledge of Divine things, which commonly we call Chriſtian Divinity; for whether we have reſpect to the Cauſes, the Effects, the Subjects, the Objects, the Adjuncts, or the ends thereof, it farre exceeds all the Arts, Sci • nces, Knowledge or Wiſdome that the World affords. The reſult therefore of all is, that it behoves every man that aymes at eternall happineſſe, not onely moſt highly to eſt eme it, but alſo in ſome good meaſure to attaine unto it. And therefore gentle Reader, although many have written divers excellent and ample Volumes of the whole body of Divinity, yet (as a mite caſt into the treaſurie) I hope thou wilt accept of this my weake endeavour, for thy Soules good, as an inſtrument conducing unto that end. It is indeed, but as a little Infant in compariſon with the talleſt Man; yet thou maiſt diſcerne, it has its full ſhape, as well as hath the greateſt,
and Scripture enough to prove it to be Legitimate, and therefore as I doe commend it to thy charitable cenſure (hoping thou wilt not deſpiſe it for the ſmalleſt of its growth) ſo I doe no leſſe deſire, that thou maiſt fully improve it to thy owne advantage: and to this end, I could wiſh thou wouldſt make it thy vade mecum, or thy pocket companion; that ſo in the end, by committing it to memory, it may (to thy comfort) become thy boſome friend; or as an hid treaſurie in thy heart, that may helpe to maintaine thee in thy journey to the Heavenly Jeruſalem, that ſo although it be but little, yet (if by a faithfull application thou make much of it) at laſt thou maiſt finde it, to grow great in thy Soule, to thy everlaſting comfort: and therefore doe not onely caſt an eye upon it, and ſo lay it by, but take the paines to reade it through. It is but an houres labour, or a little more, deliberately to view it over, which being done, if then thou lik'ſt it, Quo animo legis obſerva, & quo obſervas ſerva (as one ſaith well) with what affection thou readeſt it, obſerve it, and with the ſame affection thou obſerveſt it, remember it, and remember to practice it: and withall turne often to the Scriptures that (for the confirmation of thoſe truths) do ſtand in relation to each part of it; which being often revolved in thy minde, will much advantage thee in the knowledge of God, and of his revealed will. So God ſhall be glorified, thy Underſtanding enlightned, thy Faith ſtrengthned, and ſo conſequently thy Soule for ever comforted. And that ſo it may be, is, and ſhall be the prayer of him, who is thy Soules true friend,

div.head: The Epitome of DIVINITY Poetically compoſed, &c.
1. The condition of a True Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Queſt.
sp.l: WHat is a Chriſtian?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: One that in Chriſts name
Baptiz'd Act. 8. 16. Act. 2. 38. Act. 11. 16., led by his grace Rom. 8. 14, 15, 16., doth through the ſame
Believe on him Mar. 16. 16. Joh. 3. 16., continue in his Word Act. 2. 42.,
And to's example make his life accord Joh. 13. 15. Phil. 2. 5. 1 Pet 2. 21..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Anſwer me then, are they not Christians all,
That are baptiz'd, and live within the pale
Of Chriſt his Church?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No, they alone indeed
Are Chriſtians, who of the immortal ſeed,
Are born again Joh. 3. 5. 1 Pet. 1. 23., as of the element,
That uſed is, in Baptiſmes ſacrament,
For he that is Chriſts ſcholler, (what the name
Of Chriſtian doth ſignifie) the ſame Act. 22. 16. Eph. 5. 26.
Muſt be Gods childe Gal. 3. 26, 27..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Is't needfull then to be
New born?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It is Joh 3. 3..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: The reaſon why lets ſee,

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The reaſon is, man is by ſin deform'd Epheſ. 2. 1, 2.,
The childe of wrath by nature Epheſ. 2. 3., and reform'd
Muſt therefore be Epheſ. 2. 5., and made the childe of grace Epheſ. 2. 8,
If he in heaven deſires a biding place Matth. 5. 3. Gal. 6. 16 Matth. 25. 34.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Mankinde in Adam was created good?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: True Gen. 1. 26, 31., and might be ſo ſtill had Adam ſtood Wiſd. 2. 23. Eccleſ. 7. 31.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How then became it ſinfull?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Through the fall
Of Adam Gen. 3. 6., by whom ſin paſs'd over all Rom. 5. 12..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Adam as the head of whole mankind Gen. 3. 20.,
What ſo ere gifts of body, or of mind,
He did in his creation from the grace
Of God receive Jam 1. 17., the ſame for his whole race
He had, as for himſelf Eccleſ. 7. 31., and therefore when
He loſt them by his fall, all other men
Loſt them in him; nor onely ſo, but he
Being defil'd by this tranſgreſſion, we
That in his loynes were hid, did then begin,
Though yet we had not being to have ſin:
For being of the propagated maſs
Begotten, all which then in Adam was,
And was in him by his firſt fault defil'd,
It follows, that ev'ry ſucceeding childe
Of his, muſt ſinfull be Rom. 5. 12, 14., for who can bring
A clean ſtream from a foul and pudled ſpring Job 14. 4.?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Are all men ſinners then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes, there is none
Excepted Prov. 20. 9. 1 Joh. 1. 8., but our Saviour CHRIST alone 1 Pet. 2. 22. 1 Joh. 3. 5..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Sinners deſerve death, and is death to all
Ʋs due, for having ſin originall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Onely for this we doe deſerve to die,
Though we had elſe done none iniquity Rom. 5. 12. & 6. 23.:
But we doe many waies offend beſides Jam. 3. 6.,
Becauſe that Mother ſin that ſtill abides
In us Pſ. 51. 6. Rom. 7. 8., depraving both the minde, and will Rom. 7. 13, 14, 15.;
Breeds alwaies, and brings forth ſome actuall ill Jam. 1. 5.:
And whatſoe're we doe, or think, or ſay,
Is ſin Rom. 3. 9, 10. Job 25. 4.: and God therefore condemn us may Pſal. 51. 4. & 143. 2..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How know we this, what is the rule whereby,
We doe our actions, to be ſinfull try?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The Morall Law Rom. 7. 7., divided into ten
Eternall precepts, Gods own Word, which when
Sinai was all on ſmoke, the ayre with thunder
Ratled, and lightning ſhone, that men did wonder,
And mountain quak'd (the trumpet being ſounded)
Was by JEHOVAH, in ſuch ſort propounded Exod. cap. 20..

lg.l: I am the Lord that made, and doe command,
The heav'n, the fire, the aire, the ſea, the land,
With all things in them Gen. cap. 1. Pſal. 89. 11, yea thy God I am;
Thy Saviour that from the land of Ham,
And houſe of bondage, did thee Iſr'el bring See Exod. the 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 • 2. chapters & Pſal. 106. 22.,
By a ſtrong Arm, and Power aſtoniſhing Pſal. 136. •• ..

lg.head: I.
lg.l: HAve thou no other Gods but me alone,
Whoſe might, and mercy, to thee have been ſhewn Mat 4. 10..

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Make to thy ſelf no image, carve, nor paint,
In heaven above, of Angel, or of Saint,
In ſea of fiſh, in earth of any creature,
For a religious uſe, the fanſied feature:
Neither ſhalt thou ſerve it, nor it adore,
Though but with bodies bending, and no more Deut. 4. 15, to the 20. Act. 17. 29 Levit. 26. 1. Pſal. 97. 7..
For I JEHOVAH am a jealous God Exod. 34. 14. Nahum. 1. 2. Deut. 32. 21.,
That doe ſeverely viſit with my rod,
The fathers ſins, on their poſterity,
Extending to the third, and fourth degree
Of their ſucceeding iſſue, that me hate,
And for a god, an idol conſecrate Lam. 5. 7.:
But mercy ſhew to them, and thouſands more
Of them, that love me, and obſerve my lore Pſal. 128. 3, 6. Deut. 28. 4..

lg.head: III.
lg.l: My ſacred name, or attributes forbear
To uſe irreverently, and doe not ſwear
Falſly, or raſhly by me Lev. 19. 12. Mat. 5. 33, 34., for excus'd
Ile hold him not, by whom my names abus'd Deut. 28. 58. to the end. Jen. 23. 10..

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: By pious works, and a religious reſt,
Remember that thou keep my weekly feaſt,
The bleſſed Sabbath: Six daies ſhalt thou doe,
What work ſoever thou art call'd unto:
But on the ſeventh, which is the Sabbath day,
Of God thy Lord, no work nor labour may
Be by thy ſelf done, or allow'd to be
Done, by thy ſalve, beaſt, gueſt, that is with thee Exod. 23. 12. Ezek. 20. 12. Iſa. 58. 12, 13. Neh. 13. 15. to ver. 22.:
For in ſix daies, the Lord the heavens did frame,
The earth, the ſea, with what is in the ſame;
But on the ſeventh day, he was pleaſ'd to reſt;
And therefore hath it ſanctifi'd and bleſt Gen. 2. 1, 2..

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Honour thy parents, and obſerve with love
And reverence due thoſe that are thee above Eph. 6. 1, 2. Exod. 21. 17. Col. 3. 20. Matth 19. 19. Matth. 15. 4.
In gifts 1 Tim. 5. 17., place Col. 3. 22., office Rom. 13. 1. Eccleſ. 8. 2. 1 Pet. 2. 13. Prov. 24. 21., or whoſe love, and care,
Towards thee Gen. 45. 8. Job 31. 18., or whoſe age, make that they are
Fathers, or mothers, to thee, that thou live
Long, in the land, which to thee God ſhall give 1 Tim. 5. 1, 2. Levit. 19. 32..

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Mans blood in cruelty thou ſhalt not ſpill Gen. 9. 5, 6.,
Nor ſhalt in malice ſeek Mat. 5. 22. Eph. 4. 31. 1 Cor. 14: 21. 1 Pet. 2. 1. or wiſh his ill 1 Pet. 3. 9..

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Doe not by carnall acts Eph. 5. 3. Heb. 13. 4., or luſts moſt vile,
Thy own or others purity defile 2 Sam. 13. 4. Lev. 18. 6, 23. Rom. 1. 24, 26, 27. Mat. 5. 28..

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Thy neighbours goods, by any unjuſt way,
Thou ſhalt not to thy proper uſe convey Exod. 22. 1, 2, 3. Lev. 6. 2, 3..

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: By an abuſive or a lying tongue,
Thy neighbour, or his fame, thou ſhalt not wrong Pſ. 15. 3. Prov. 6. 19. & 20. 19..

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Thy neighbours houſe, his wife, his ſervant, maid,
His beaſt, or other thing that may be ſaid
His, muſt thou not luſt after, neither muſt
Thou yeeld to, or be mov'd by any luſt Luke 12. 15. 1 Tim. 6. 6. to the 11. to ſee the hainouſneſs and puniſhment of this ſin, read 1 Kin. ch. 21..
This is Gods law, which who doth not fulfill
In every jot and tittle, he doth ill Deut. 5. 32. & 28. 15. to the end..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is the ſumme hereof?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: This, thou ſhalt love
The Lord thy God, who dwells above, above
All things; with all thy powers Mat. 22. 37., let neighbour be,
As thou art to thy ſelf, ſo dear to thee Mat. 22. 39, 40.

div.head: 4. No man is able to keep the Law.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Is any man of power all this to doe,
Which God in this his Law commands unto?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Not any man Eccleſ. 7. 22., not the moſt ſanctifi'd 2 Cor. 3. 5.,
As doth appear, being by this rule try'd Gal. 3. 10.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Why then doth God command what cannot be
Perform'd by any man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Surely when he
Before the fall, did in mans minde engrave
The Law Rom. 2. 15., ſtrength to perform the ſame he gave Eccleſ. 7. 31.;
Which ſith by his own fault he loſt Gen. 3. 6, God ſtill
Juſtly requires obedience to his will Mie. 6. 9..
Beſides though men not call'd, by no means can
In any point perform the Law Heb. 11. 6. Joh. 1. 5., that man
Who is new born, can it ſo farre obſerve,
That though his works from that perfection ſwerve,
Which God in's righteous juſtice doth expect 1 Ioh 3. 9. Luke 1. 6. Pſal. 119. 3.,
Are yet ſo good, that he doth them reſpect 2 Cor. 8. 12
In mercy for Chriſts ſake, who hath ſuppli'd,
What he doth want by having ſatisfi'd
On his behalf 1 Cor. 1. 30..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But ſith in meaſure due
It cannot be perform'd, no not ſay you,
By the new-born themſelves; ſpeak what may be
The uſe thereof?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Its offices are three:
The one ſpirituall, 'cauſe it doth pertain
To thoſe, who by Gods Spirit are born again;
Whom it doth teach, to worſhip God aright,
And walk preciſely as in his pure ſight Pſalm 116. 1, to the end..
A ſecond outward, ſerving to repreſs
The fear of puniſhment for wickedneſs,
Ev'n of ungodly men, ſo farre that they
Dare not break out, into what ſins they may Rom. 2. 14, 15. Mat. 21. 26..
A third more ſecret, when it ſore affecteth
The conſcience for ſin, which it detecteth,
Reproves, condemns, and threatens puniſhment
Eternall, to be therefore conſequent Rom. 7. 7, to the 24. Gen. 4. 7. 13, 14. Mat. 27. 4..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: After the Law hath thus ſhew'd us our ſin,
And miſerable eſtate that we are in;
Doth it not alſo ſhew the remedy,
Vhereby to cure our ſinfull malady
And to prevent damnation?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No Rom. 7. 11. 2 Cor. 3. 5., but this,
• erformed onely by the Goſpel is 1 Cor. 15. 1 to the 5. Eph. 1. 7. 1 Tim. 4. 9, 10. Tit. 2..

div.head: 5. The knowledge of the Law leads us to imbrace the Gospel.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is the Gospel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It's Gods heavenly Word Luke 2. 10, 11.,
Promiſ'd to th' fathers, by Gods Son our Lord Heb. 1. 1.,
And his Apoſtles Mat. 4. 18, 19. Heb. 1. 2., men inſpired by
His bleſſed Spirit, declared perfectly Act. 2. 3, 4. 2 Pet. 1. 21.,
Bringing the joyfull news that by the Son
Of God procured is redemption
For all mankinde 2 Tim. 3. 16. 1 Tim. 2. 6. 1 Pet. 1. 18, 19, 20. (ſo that they will amend Mat. 3. 2.,
And will believe 1 Pet. 1. 21.) life, bliſs without an end Tit. 1. 2. Joh. 10. 28..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is the Gospels ſubject?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Is he
Ordain'd by God, the remedy to be,
For ſinfull man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: He is 1 Theſſ. 5. 9.; and there is none
That hath ſalvation wrought but he alone Acts 4. 11, 12..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: To know Chriſt then is't neceſſary?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes:
For to know God, and Chriſt, is happineſs Joh. 17. 3..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What's God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: One eſſence pure Deut. 6. 4. Exod. 3. 14., in perſons three
Father, Son, holy Ghoſt 1 John 5. 17. Mat. 3. 16, 17., who though they be
Diſtinct in properties, (as doe imply
Their ſev'rall names Eph 4. 6. Joh. 1. 14. Rom. 8. 16.) agree in unity
Of nature 1 Joh. 5. 7., being one 1 Cor 8. 4., great Pſal. 139. 7. Iſa. 66. 1., infinite Pſal. 90. 2.,
In wiſdome Rom. 11. 33., power Phil. 3. 21., goodneſs Exod. 34. 6., bleſſed Sprite 1 Tim 1. 11..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Sufficeth it for man God thus to know,
As he is in himſelf conſid'red?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No Joh. 4. 24.:
But it is chiefly needfull to ſalvation,
That we doe know God, as he hath relation
Towards us 1 Cor. 8. 2, 3., which is, when we underſtand
Aright in God, his perfect juſtice, and
His perfect mercy 1 Cor. 8. 5, 6. 1 Joh. 2. 5. Pſal. 85. 10..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Speak then, what are they?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Not qualities, for that's moſt falſe to ſay;
But God his juſtice, is his nature Pſal. 48. 10. Deut. 32. 4., as
It hates all evill, nor lets any paſs
Unpuniſht Exod. 20. 5.: mercy is the ſame, as it
Gives freely to us, every benefit
We doe enjoy Pſal. 36. 5, 7. Tit. 3. 5. Exod. 20. 5..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But when eſpecially
Appear'd this mercy?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: When God graciouſly Eph. 2. 4, 5, 6.
Gave us his Chriſt Joh. 3. 16., who is the ſumme, and chief
Of all Gods benefits, the ſouls relief 1 Joh. 3. 7.:
And whom it is moſt needfull that we know,
The reaſon why, I did but lately ſhow.

div.head: 6. What muſt be known concerning Chriſt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What muſt be known concerning Chriſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What doe
Concern his perſon, and his office too Joh 1. 1, to the 15. Gal. 4 4. Phil. 2. 6, 7..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: Touching his perſon, what is he?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Gods Son Mat. 3. 17. Luke 1. 35. Joh. 1. 14, 18.
Who by a ſacred, ſecret union
Hath joyn'd our nature to his deity,
In one admired, bleſt, ſubſiſtency Col. 2. 9. 2. Pet. 1. 4. Ioh 17. 21. Heb. 2. 11.:
And ſo is God, and man, and yet but one
Perſon, one Chriſt, and but one God alone 1 Cor. 8 6. 1 Tim. 2. 5. ▪

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But was it needfull that who mankinde ſhould
Redeem be God Almighty, neither could
Any nor all the creatures this effect?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Undoubtedly they could not in reſpect
Both of the evils great which damnifi'd
Us, and the great good things which none beſide
God could reſtore unto us 1 Pet. 1. 18 19, 20..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Them great evils,
What are they tell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Sins heavy weight 1 Cor. 15 56., the devils
Baſe tyrannie 2 Tim. 2. 26., death's conqueſt, and the ſenſe
Of Gods juſt wrath conceiv'd 'gainſt mans offence Col. 3. 6. Eph. 2. 3.;
Which for to take away Ioh. 1 29. 1 Ioh. 2 1, 2., ſubdue, confound,
And pacifie, no creature could be found,
But God muſt doe it Heb. 2. 14. 1 Ioh. 3. 8..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: Say what good things are
Reſtor'd unto us?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What ſin once did marre,
And did in our firſt parents quite deface Rom. 5. 15. to the end.,
Wiſdome, true holineſſe, and every grace 1 Cor. 1. 30.,
Whereby Gods image is in us reform'd Epheſ. 4. 23, 24. 2 Cor. 15. 49.;
Now this could not be, but by God perform'd 2 Epheſ. 4, to the 11..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: God is omnipotent, and all things can,
Was't needfull then, that God ſhould become man
To ſave mankinde?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Though in his power he
Could ſave by other means, it did agree
Beſt with his juſtice, us ſo to redeem Heb. 2. 10, 14.,
Becauſe man having ſinned, it doth ſeem
Moſt juſt, that man ſhould make amends Rom 8. 3, 4., and by
That nature that offended ſatisfie
Almighty God Gal. 3. 13..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But anſwer, whether might
Not God the Father, nor the bleſſed Sprite
Act the Redeemers part, incarnate be,
As God the Son?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: They might, but Gods decree
Ordain'd before that mankindes reparation,
Should be by him Iſa. 9. 6, 7. Gal. 4. 4., by whom was its creation Ioh. 1. 3..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Of Chriſt himſelf this to have ſaid ſufficeth:
What is his office?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: That he exerciſeth,
According to both natures, as he is Chriſt Rom. 9. 5. 1 Tim. 3. 16. Rom. 1. 2, 3.,
Or our anointed King Rev. 19. 16., Prophet Deut. 18. 15., and Prieſt Pſal. 110. 4..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is his Regall office?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: That whereby
He ruleth all things, but eſpecially,
His Church Jer. 23. 5. Luke 1. 33., which he defends Jer. 23. 6., endows with graces
Here Eph. 4. 8.; and doth glorifie in heavenly places Joh. 10. 28..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the parts hereof?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The parts I name,
A calling by the Word Hag. 2. 7. Heb. 4. 12., and by the ſame
A judging, that is either generall,
When he doth all men generally call Mat. 22. 9, 10. 1 Cor. 1. 9.;
And doth invite 2 Theſſ. 11. 12. to faith, by his Word's preaching Rom. 10. 17. 1 Theſſ. 2. 13.,
Or ſpecially, when unto the outward teaching 2 Tim. 1. 9.,
He joynes his ſpirits working, and inflecteth
The minde, that it believeth, and affecteth
Gods Word 1 Joh. 5. 6, 10. Rom. 8. 11, to 16.; And this doth not to all belong,
As doth the outward calling of the tongue Mat. 22. 3, & 8 verſes, & 11. to the 15.
But to Gods choſen onely, theſe alone
Are called effectually, not every one Rom. 8. 30. Rom. 9. 11, 12, 13..
The other part of Chriſt his Office royall,
Is that whereby, he doth on his diſloyall
Subjects, the wicked, puniſhments inflict
In this life Pſal. 2, 9. & 110. 1, 2., and when after by his ſtrict
Juſtice, he hath before his Judgment-ſeat,
Summon'd, arraign'd, condemn'd them in his great
And dreadfull indignation; he them ſendeth
Thence into Hell, where torment never endeth Mat. 22. 11, 12, 13. & 8. 12. & 25. 41..
But thoſe who are his ſervants, his elect,
He doth againſt his enemies protect Joh. 16. 33. Rom. 16. 20.,
Acquit them of their ſins, in the laſt day Rom. 8. 32. to the end.,
And them reward ev'n with an heavenly pay Mat. 25. 34..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How was a Prophets Office, by our Lord
Chriſt executed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: When he by his Word Col. 3. 16.,
His Spirit Luke 24. 45., Sacraments Mat. 26. 26, 27, 28. & 28. 20., himſelf Heb. 1. • Mat. 28 20., and his

Ordained Miniſters Act. 5. 20, 21. Mat. 2 •
〈…〉 . 20., made known what is
The Goſpel, or his heavenly Fathers minde,
Concerning the redemption of mankinde Rom. 1. 1, 2, 3, 4..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is his Prieſtly Office?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: That whereby,
He did Gods wrath, againſt us pacifie 1 Theſſ. 1. 10. Heb. 5. 8, 9, 10.;
And put himſelf, a gracious Mediatour,
'Twixt ſinfull man, and God his juſt Creatour 1 Tim. 2. 5. Heb. 7. 24, 25. 1 Joh. 2. 1, 2..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the parts hereof?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Two: ſatisfaction,
When he the Law fulfill'd in holy action Mat. 3. 15. & 5. 17.,
And gave his life as a redeeming price
For us Mat. 20. 28. 1 Tim. 2. 6., and made himſelf a ſacrifice
For ſin Heb. 9. 11. to the end. upon the Croſs Mat. 27. 24, 26. 1 Pet. 2. 24.; and interceſſion Rom. 8. 34. Hebr. 7. 25.;
Whereby now ſtanding in the full poſſeſſion
Of glory Phil. 2. 9, 10. Heb. 7. 25.; he deſires, his offering may
Prevail with God, for his elect Joh. 17. 9, to the end., and they
May have their ſuits, and prayers granted ſtill Joh. 16. 23, 24, 26, 27.,
When they are made according to his will 1 Ioh. 5. 14, 15..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Of CHRIST his Perſon, and his Office both,
Is ſaid enough, and now it plainly doth
Appear, how CHRIST is made our remedy:
But remedies though made, if none apply
Them to the patient, doe not heal, ſhew then,
How CHRIST applied is to us, and when.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: He is appli'd, made ours, this way alone;
By being joyned with us, and made one Heb. 3. 15. Ioh. 17. 21, 22, 23..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How, ſpeak wherein this union doth conſiſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: In this, that we remain and live in Chriſt,
And he in us, that each is held poſſeſt
Of other, by a ſpeciall intereſt 1 Cor. 1. 9. Ioh. 14. 19, 20. Gal. 2. 20.:
So that we are his branches Ioh. 15. 5., and his wife Hoſ. 2. 19, 20.,
His parts 1 Cor. 12. 27., and draw to us, growth Col. 2. 19., gifts Eph. 4. 7, 8., & life Ioh. 6. 47, 48.;
From him our vine Ioh. 15. 1., our husband Cant. 4. 8, 16., and our head 1 Cor. 11. 3.,
By which we grow, proſper, and are quickned Eph. 2. 5.:
And he doth take on him by imputation,
Our ſins 2 Cor. 5. 21., and bears our woes, by his compaſſion 1 Pet. 2. 24. Heb. 4. 15..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is it that we by this union have?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What thing ſoever needfull is to ſave Rom. 8. 32. 2 Pet. 1. 3.,
Whole Chriſt himſelf 2 Pet. 1. 4. Heb. 2 14. Eph. 5. 30. 1 Cor. 6. 17., his merits, every good,
Which the bleſt virtue of his fleſh and blood
May yeild 1 Cor. 1. 30, Rom. 8. 32..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the parts of it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I call
The parts theſe, imputation, and reall,
Or an habituall infuſion:
The firſt is when, what Chriſt in's paſſion
Suffred, and acted by his holineſs;
Imputed is to us, for righteouſneſs 2 Cor. 5. 21..
The ſecond when, grace in ſome meaſure, is
Beſtowed here Epheſ. 4. 7. 1 Pet. 5. 10, but plenteouſly in bliſs 1 Cor. 13. 9, 10, 12..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is this unions bond, the ſacred tie,
That Chriſt and us conjoyneth mutually?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The Holy Ghoſt 1 Cor. 12. 3.; for as the members be
All knit unto the head by nerves, ſo he,
By his internall operation, knits
Us unto Chriſt, with all his benefits 1 Cor. 1. 30. & 12. 12, 13..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Doth not he work this by ſome inſtruments?

div.head: 9. The means of our unity Ioh. 1. 12. Phil. 3. 9. to Chriſt.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes: theſe, our faith, Gods word Rom. 10. 17., and ſacraments Rom 6. 3, 4, 5, 6. 1 Cor. 10. 16, 17..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: By faith how?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Faith he gives Phil. 1. 29. Matth. 16. 17., and ſo doth make
Us able, of Chriſt Jeſus to partake Eph. 3. 17. Ioh. 1. 12.:
For faith is to the ſoul, an hand extended,
Whereby Chriſt (though above) is apprehended,
And brought home to it 1 Pet. 1. 7, 8, 9. Rom. 1. 16, 17. & 5. 1, 2..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How doe you define
This faith?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It is a quality divine Phil 1. 29. Heb. 11. 1. Mat. 16. 17.,
By which we know and doe aſſent unto
Gods word Joh. 2. 22. and promiſes in Chriſt, and doe
Confide therein Rom. 4. 16, to 21., and know moſt certainly Job 19. 25, 26, 27.
That God in Chriſt doth love us graciouſly Joh. 3. 16, 17..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Who is the author of this faith?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The Lord Phil. 1. 6, & 29. 2 Cor. 3. 45.,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: The object what?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The Generall, his Word Joh. 5. 46, 47. Exod. 14. 31. Ioh. 2. 22.
The Speciall, that part which concerns his Son
Chriſt crucifi'd Ioh. 1. 15. Rom. 8. 9, 10, 11., our faith's foundation 1 Pet. 2. 6. Act. 4. 11, 12..
The ſumme whereof we have ſet down in brief
In the twelve Articles of our belief
Which if you pleaſe I will repeat and ſhow
The ſenſe of them, but briefly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Be it ſo.

div.head: 10. The Belief.

sp.speaker: A
sp.l: My faith's firſt object, & my faith's ſole Author,
Is God in eſſence, but in perſon Father Eph. 3. 14, 15, 16, 17. Mat. 16. 17.,
Almighty in his power 1 Chron. 29. 11, 12. Pſal. 145. 6., the earth's great founder
And heavens builder Gen. 1, to the 11., which about doth round her 2 Chron. 2. 6.
Next Chriſt in office Rev. 19 16. Deut. 18. 15. Pſal. 110. 4., Jeſus by his name Mat. 1. 31.,
Gods Son in perſon Pſal. 2. 7. Mat. 3. 17. Rom. 1. 2, 3., yet with God the ſame Ioh. 1. 1, 2.;
Props up my faith Act. 4. 11, 12., whom I believe to be
My Lord God man, in one hypoſtaſie Gal 4 4, 5.,
Born of a Virgin Iſa. 7 14., whoſe pure womb his ſeat
Was made, by th' vertue of the paraclete Luke 1. 35.,
Condemn'd by Pilate Mat. 27 24, 26. on the Croſſe did die
A ſhamefull death Luke 23. 46., dead in the grave did lie Mar. 15. 46.;
So alſo into Hell he did deſcend;
The truth whereof ev'n thus me may defend:
In Gethſamane he ſuffred by's agony Mar. 14. 3., to the 37.,
So likewiſe upon the Croſſe (when he did cry
ELOI, ELOI, LAMASABACHTHANI Mar. 15. 34?)
The helliſh torments due to thoſe that die
In their ſins, without regeneration,
And ſo not capable of Gods compaſſion Mat. 26. 37, 38, 39. Mat. 27. 46. 1 Pet. 2. 24. 2 Cor. 5. 21..
Then after, on the third day he did riſe Luke 24. 6, 7. Iohn 2, 19.,
Triumphant Victor ore his enemies Pſal. 2. 9. 1 Cor. 15, 55, 56, 57.,
Aſcend to heaven Luke 24. 51. Ioh. 3. 13, 14. where inthronized Rev. 20. 11.,
He ſits Mar. 16. 19. till he ſhall judge the quick and dead 2 Cor. 5. 10. Rev. 20. 12, 13..
The third main pillar of my faith is he,
Who though proceeding (to make up the three
Perſons) both from the Father and the Son,
Yet is not made, becauſe with them he's one Gal. 4. 6. 2 Ioh. 5. 7, 8.;
Who doth reſtore in us, our goodneſs loſt
By ſin 1 Cor. 6. 11., whence he is call'd the Holy Ghoſt 2 Iohn 5. 7..
An univerſall Church of Saints above Heb. 12. 22, 23.,
And here united by the bond of love;
I doe believe to be 1 Cor. 12. 12, to the end, 2 Phil. 1, to the 6. 2 Col. 19., in that I live 1 John 1. 3.,
Whoſe ſins through Chriſt his Son God doth forgive Iſa. 53. 4, to the end. Dan. 9. 24. Mat. 1. 21. 1 Cor. 18, 19, 21.:
And will me raiſe, though dead 'mongſt other men 1 Cor. 15. 12, to the end. Iob 19. 25, 26, 27.,
And bring me j to eternall life 1 Pet. 1. 3, 4, 5. Heb. 9. 15. Phil. 3. 21. AMEN.

div.p: [As the Apoſtles Creed is the ſum of the whole Goſpel, or as an abſtract of the New Testament: ſo theſe eight lines following are the ſumme of that Creed, and therefore needs no further proof.]

sp.l: This is the Creed, whoſe ſumme, and ſenſe is this:
I doe confide, and put my hope of bliſſe,
In one Chriſt crucifi'd, who given me by
The Fathers mercy, doth ſpiritually
Impart himſelf unto his Church, and me
By God the Holy Ghoſt to make me be,
Partaker of his deaths moſt pretious merit,
And that I may eternall life inherit.

div.head: 11. How we are juſtified by faith in Chriſt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Then you make Chriſt the ſcope & ground of faith.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I doe Rom. 3. 24, 25., and hence it is the Apoſtle ſaith
Faith juſtifies Rom. 5. 1. Gen. 15. 6. Rom. 4. 24. & 3. 28..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Not as 'tis a grace compare Rom. 4. 5. with Rom. 10. 10.,
But as it doth our Saviour Chriſt imbrace Gal. 2. 16.,
Who is our righteouſneſs Phil. 3. 9. Iohn 1. 12..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is it then
To juſtifie us ſinners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It is when
For Chriſt his ſake (who both in life and death
Fulfill'd the Law for us Rom. 5. 17, 18, 19.) God pardoneth
Freely our ſins Rom. 3. 24, 25. Eph. 1. 7. Acts 10. 43., condemns us not to die Rom. 5. 9, 10. Iohn 3. 16.,
Imputes unto us to eternity
The righteouſneſs of Chriſt 1 Cor. 1. 30. 2 Cor. 5. 19, 21., wherewith array'd
By faith Rev. 16 15. (as if we had our ſelves obey'd
The whole Law perfectly) we in Gods ſight,
Holy and pure appear, as is the light Rom 5. 18, 19. This place gives the reaſon of the whole anſwer..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Sith faith ſo needfull is, I'de have you tell,
By what ſignes may we know that Chriſt doth dwell
In us by faith?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: By theſe, regeneration 2 Cor. 5. 17. 1 Iohn 3. 24. Rom. 6. 4. Acts 20. 21.,
And by the Spirits ſecret revelation 1 Cor. 6. 11 & 1 Cor. 2. 10. Iohn 14. 16, 17. 1 Iohn 5. 6.:
For it doth with our ſpirits witneſs bear,
That we are Gods ſons, ſo that ſervile fear
Remov'd as children we dare faithfully,
To God Almighty, Abba, Father, cry Rom. 8. 14, 15, 16..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What is Regeneration?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: A renewing
Of minde, will, the whole man, or an endowing
Of them with holy qualities Tit. 3. 5. Ezek 36. 25, 26, 27. 2 Cor. 5. 17., for in
Whom Chriſt's Spirit, and faith are, there no ſin
Can reign 1 Iohn 3. 9. & 5. 18..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the parts thereof expreſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Sin-killing, and a life of righteouſneſs Rom. 6. 1, to 5. Col. 3. 9, 10..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: 'Tis by degrees for to deſtroy,
(Through Chriſt his death) ſin that doth moſt annoy
The ſoul, that from thenceforth it is no more,
So potent to deprave, as 'twas before Rom. 6. 6. & 12. 14. & 21. 23..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the means on our part, by which we
May ſin ſubdue?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Eſpecially theſe three:
The ſight of ſin Pſal. 5 1. 3, 4, 5. 1 Iohn 1. 8, 9. through ſelf-examination Pſal 4. 4. Gal. 6. 4.,
Next Godly-ſorrow Pſal. 51. 17. 2 Cor. 7. 9, 10, 11., with ſins deteſtation Rom. 6. 21 & 12. 9..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is that other part, the which you call
A life of righteouſneſs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It is when all
Our faculties throughout, being reform'd
By God the Holy Ghoſt, there are perform'd Eph. 4. 23, 24. Rom. 6. 19.
Such actions by them, as which God requires Gal. 5. 22, 23, 25.;
The Minde knows the true God Col. 1. 10. 1 Iohn 2. 3, 5., the Will deſires
Him Pſal. 63. 1, 5, 8., the Affections doe the ſame purſue Col. 3. 2.,
And every part acteth its office due Rom. 6. 1 • ..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Follows it then, what you doe ſeem to ſay
That in whom Christ abideth, onely they
Live holy?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes, ev'n as ſurely as they live,
Who have a ſoul, which to them life doth give Iohn 15. 5. 2 Cor. 5. 17.:
And therefore though faith juſtifies alone Rom. 3. 28.;
The faith that works not, juſtifieth none James 2. 14, 15, 16, 17, 26..
For as faith us (as the Apoſtle ſayeth)
Doth juſtifie Rom. 5. 1.: ſo works makes juſt our faith Iam. 2. 18, 21, to 24..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What works?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Such works as both the cauſes whence
They come, the love of God Gal. 5. 6. 1 Ioh. 2. 5. & 5. 2, 3., & conſcience
Of Duty 2 Cor. 1. 12. Act. 24. 16., faith in Chriſt 1 Pet. 1. 5, to 8., and ſo the end,
Gods glorifying, unto which they tend 1 Cor. 10. 31. Rom. 11. 36. Rev. 4. 11.,
Make pleaſing unto God Rom. 12. 12. 1 Theſ. 4. 1. Eph. 5. 8, 9, 10., and doe agree
(In ſome ſort) with Gods law Rom. 7. 22., although they be
Not abſolutely perfect Luke 17. 10..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What 'mongst all
Thoſe good works, doe you think moſt principall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Prayer for this is the moſt evident
Signe of our faith, that we are confident
On Gods love to us, ſith we dare deſire
Of him thoſe good things which our wants require Mat. 22, to the 29.:
Yea, by the help of this, we get the ſtrength,
Whereby to doe all other works at length Iohn 16. 23. Mat. 7. 7, to the 12..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But what is Prayer?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: An affection
Of heart devout Pſal. 62. 8., whereby we call upon
God to avert ill from us Pſal. 50. 15., and to grant
Unto us ſuch good things as we doe want Jam. 1. 5.:
Which we believe through Chriſt he will afford
Us John 16. 23., asking them according to his word Jam. 1. 6. 1 John 5. 14, Matth. 7. 21..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But dareth ſinfull man by invocation
Soli it God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes through the mediation
Of JESUS CHRIST John 14. 13, 14., our onely Advocate 1 Joh. 2. 12. 1 Tim. 2. 5.,
In whom our prayers pleaſe and impetrate John 14. 13, 14..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Why ſay you onely; Doe not Saints likewiſe,
This work of interceding exerciſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: They doe not Pſal 115. 17., for they know not what we have
Need of 1 Cor. 2. 11.; beſides ſith Chriſt alone doth ſave Acts 4. 12. 1 Theſ. 5. 9.,
And ſaith that whatſoever (in his name)
We ask the Father, he will give the ſame John 16. 23.;
Why ſhould we, nay how dare we in the ſtead John 14. 6.
Of Chriſt think Saints ſhoud intercede!

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the things which we muſt pray unto
God for with hope of being heard?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What doe
Concern God's glory firſt Mat. 6. 9, 10. being the 3 firſt Petitions of the Lords Prayer., next our ſouls good Pſal. 51. 1, to the 13.,
Then needfull things for life, as cloath's and food Prov. 30. 8.,
And therefore that we ſhould not pray amiſs,
For things unlawfull, what our nature is
Apt to ſeek after Iames ch. 1. ver. 6, 7. & 3. chap. ver. 3., Chriſt himſelf did teach
What good things are, and in what order each
Is to be pray'd for, in that Form which he
Preſcrib'd to his Diſciples, and which we
Call the Lords Prayer Mat. 6. 9, to the 13. Luke 11. 2, 3, 4..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Now this therefore ſay
And give its ſenſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Then Chriſt doth bid us pray
OƲr Fatther, full of mercy Pſal 123. 2, 3. Epheſ. 2. 4. Exod. 20. 6. & 34. 6, 7. and of love John 3. 16. 1 John 3. 1. & 4 9. Rom. 5. 5, 8.;
Which art: though every where Pſal. 139. 6, to the 13., in Heaven above,
Chiefly in glory ſhining 1 Kings 8. 29, 43. Pſal. 123. 1. Iſa. 66. 1., Hallowed be,
By pious works 1 Cor. 10. 31. Mat. 5. 16., ſpeeches Pſal. 19. 14. & 47. 6, 7., & thoughts of thee Pſal. 103. 1, 2.,
Thy name Pſal. 83. 18.: thy ſacred Attributes Pſal. 89. 11, to 14. and Word 2 Theſ. 3. 1. Pſal. 147. 19, 20.:
Thy Kingdome come Iſa. 9. 7.: as a moſt mighty LORD,
Shew forth thy power 1 Cor. 4. 20. Rev. 4. 10, 11., in confounding thoſe, Mat. 6. 9. Iſa. 64. 8, 9. Luke 11. 13. Rom. 8. 15.
That doe maliciouſly thy Church oppoſe Pſal. 68. 1, & 18.:
And Rule thou in it, by thy Spirits grace Eph 3. 14 to the end. Gal 6. 16.,
And make it to behold thy glorious face Pſal 27. 8, 9. Num. 6. 24, 25. 1 Cor. 13. 12.:
Thy will: thy Law Pſal 119. 1.. be done Acts 21. 14.; obſerved by
Us men in earth Pſal. 119, 32, 33, 34. and that ſo readily
As it is by thy bleſſed Spirits that reign
With thee in heaven Pſal 103 20, 21. Heb. 1. 6, 7., ſo free from ſin and pain Mat. 22. 30. Luke 20. 36.
Give Jam 1. 5.; for we challenge nothing as an hire Gen. 32. 10.,
Ʋs, that doe for the common good deſire 1 Tim. 2. 1. Jam. 5. 16.,
This day; this time, (for we no longer live
Than thou unto us of thy grace doſt give Deut. 8. 7, to the 18.)
Our, wrought for by us Gen. 3. 19. 1 Theſ. 3. 10, 11, 12., though not merited Deut. 9. 4. 5, 6.,
Daily; ſufficient for the preſent Mat. 6. 34., bread,
Our ſouls food, Chriſt John 6. 48, to the 58., and every benefit
Needfull, to maintain life, or ſtrengthen it Gen. 18. 4, to the 9. Mat. 4. 4..

And forgive us our treſpaſſes
Mat. 18. 24. Rom. 3. 9, to the 24. Pſal. 130. 3, 4., be pleaſ'd
For Chriſt his merit ſake to be appeaſ'd,
Towards us, and doe thou not us condemn Rom. 3. 24, 25, 26 John 5. 24. Rom. 8. 1.
(Though we deſerve death Rom. 5. 12.) As we forgive men
That trespaſſe againſt us Mat. 6. 14, 15., as we doe thoſe
Love and imbrace as friends, that are our foes Mat. 5. 44, 45..
And lead us not, permit us not to fall Luke 22. 31, 32.,
Whoſe nature's frail Rom. 7. 33, 34., whoſe ſtrength is none at all 2 Chro. 20. 12. 2 Cor. 3. 5. Acts 15. 10..
Into temptation 1 Cor. 1. 13. Jam. 1. 13, 14.: or to be miſled
Into impiety or vanquiſhed
By Satan, But deliver us from evil 2 Cor. 13. 7. John 17. 15.:
Preſerve us from the malice of the Devil 2 Cor. 12. 7, 8. Rom. 16. 20..
And from the danger of the fleſh Rom. 7. 5, 18. & 8. 5, 6, 7, 8., and world 1 Joh. 5. 4, 5.,
Leſt after into Hell we ſhould be hurl'd,
For thine is (onely thine) the kingdome, none
Doth reign in earth, but under thee alone,
Chief King of kings 1 Chro. 29. 11. Deut. 10. 17. Rev. 19. 16.. The power what it will
Effecting 2 Chro. 20. 6. Iſa. 50. 2, 3. 1 Chro. 29. 12., and the glory Rev. 4. 11. Luke 2. 14., that doth fill 1 Chro. 21. 1, 2, 3, 4. 2 Chr. 20. 12. Luke 12. 5. Mat. 23. 33.
The world with its greatneſs Num. 14. 21. Exod. 40. 34. 1 Kings 8. 11.; and delight
The Saints beyond expreſſion, that its ſight
Fully enjoy Pſal. 16. 11., for ever, both before,
All time and ever Pſal. 48. 14. & 145. 21., after 'tis no more Pſal. 90. 2.:
Amen Rev. 22. 20, 21. Eph. 3. 21.. Let it be done, for we believe,
The things that we have pray'd for, thou canſt give Jam 1. 5. 1 Cor. 4. 7..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But is it needfull that we alwaies ſay,
Our Saviours very word when we doe pray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No 'tis enough ſometimes they doe accord
In matter with this Prayer of the Lord compare Mat. 6. 9. with Luke 11. 2.,
But yet with underſtanding them to uſe,
Better it were for us, than to abuſe
Our Saviours warrant for it, ſo to doe;
By quite neglecting or contemning to
Uſe thoſe his very words, at any time;
For ſo to doe, will ſurely prove a crime,
Becauſe our Saviour bids us when we pray,
Our Father which art in heaven—Luke 11. 2. to ſay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Now you have ſhew d what things, ſhew how we muſt
Pray for them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Surely it is very juſt,
If we expect a gracious audience
From God Pſal. 4. 1. & 5. 1, 2, 3., that we ſhould pray in faith Jam. 1. 5, 6, 7. Mar. 11. 24., a ſenſe
Of our own wants Luke 15. 17, 18, 19., lowly humility Luke 18. 13, 14.,
Repentance Pſal. 51, the whole Pſalm., conſtancy 1 Theſ. 1 17. Epheſ. 6. 18., ſincerity Pſal 17. 1. & 145. 18, 19. 1 Tim. 2. 8.,
Zeal Jam. 5. 16., underſtanding 1 Cor. 14. 15., wrongs forgetting Mar. 11. 24, 25., love Mat. 5. 44. 1 Tim. 1. 2.,
With a minde wholly fixt on things above h.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: Beſides our faith, Gods Word and Sacraments
You ſaid were alſo uſed as inſtrument's See page 10.
In • oyning 〈◊〉 to Chriſt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The means whereby
God faith begetteth, and ſo doth apply
Chriſt to our ſouls, are theſe indeed Acts 2. 41, 42, 46..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What doe
You mean hereby the Word of God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The two
Moſt ſacred Teſtaments, whoſe principall
Parts we the Law and Goſpel uſe to call Gal. 4. 22, to the 28..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: To what end ſerves the preaching of the Law?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: By ſhewing us our miſery Rom. 3. 19, 20. & 7. 8. to draw
Us to deſire the ſaving remedy Gal. 3. 24.,
Such as may eaſe and cure that miſery Gal. 4. 4, 5. Rom. 10. 4. Gal. 3. 13, 14..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How doth Gods Word by the Gospels preaching
Infuſe into us faith?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: By therein teaching Rom. 10. 14, 15, 17.,
That for us who deſerve death Epheſ. 2. 3, 12., Chriſt hath dy'd Gal. 3. 13. Rom. 5. 6, 8.,
And thereby hath Gods anger pacified Epheſ. 2. 13, to the end. 2. Cor. 5. 18, 19.:
And that in him who doth believe Heb. 11. 6. Acts 16. 36. may have
Whatſo'ver things is needfull them to ſave Rom. 5 9, 10. 1 Cor. 30..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is a Sacrament, whereby you ſay,
God doth unto our ſouls his Christ convey?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: A holy ſigne ordained by the Lord Ex. 12. chapter. Mat. 28. 19. & 26. 26, 27, 28.,
Joyn'd to the gracious promiſe of his Word Rom. 15. 8. Mar. 16. 16
To ſignifie our Saviour Chriſt 1 Cor. 11. 23, to the 27., withall
His gifts Acts 2. 38, 39. 1 Cor. 10. 16., and to aſſure us that we ſhall
Enjoy them Rom. 4. 11., if (as we thereby are bound)
We doe by faith Rom. 4. 24, and an obedi'nce ſound
Continue his Rom. 6. 4. & 4. 12. 1 Sam. 15. 22..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How many Sacraments
Are there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: l'th former of the Teſtaments

Many As not onely thoſe of Circumciſion and the Paſchall Lamb, which were in ſtead of Baptiſme and the Lords Supper; but alſo ſome before, and ſome after, ſome of the Covenant of Works, as thoſe of the Tree of Life, and the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, Gen. 2. 9. and others after of the Covenant of Grace which were Sacraments extraordinary, as that of Manna and the Water flowing out of the Rock, 1 Cor. 10. 3, 4. and of the pouring out the Blood of the Sacrifices, Hebr. 9. 17, 18. & of the Land of Canaan, the Tabernacle, the Temple, the Arke of the Covenant, and many more that did relate to Chriſt., but in the Goſpel onely two:
Baptiſme Mat. 28. 19., and that which commonly we doe
Call the Lords Supper Mat. 26. 26, 27, 28.: one of our iſition
Into Chriſts body Gal. 3. 27., or our firſt admiſſion
Into his Church 1 Cor. 12. 13.: the other of our growth
In Jeſus Chriſt John 6. 44, 45, 46., and education both 1 Cor. 1. 16..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the chiefeſt things I'de have you ſhow,
Touching each Sacrament we ought to know?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I will, theſe four which repreſent;
The outward ſignes, what grace by them is meant,
What is the union of them both, and what
The manner, we doe both communicate.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the ſignes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The elements we ſee
And rites Mat. 3. 11. Gen. 17. 11. 1 Pet. 3. 20, 21. which elements we ſay to be
Chang'd, not in nature or in qualitie,
But in their uſe, 'cauſe now they ſignifie
Celeſtiall things 1 Cor. 10. 1, 2, 3., not through mans recitation
Of any words, but Chriſts own ordination 1 Cor. 11. 23, 24, 25.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the ſignified things?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The main
Is Chriſt 1 Cor. 11. 26. & 1. 1. 10, 16, 17., next him what bleſſings we obtain
In him 1 Cor. 1. 30..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What kinde of union doe you call
This of the ſignes, and things Celeſtiall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: An union relative, which doth conſiſt
In a reſpect betwixt the ſignes and Chriſt Luke 22. 19, 20.,
Whereby with them preſented to the ſenſe
He's offer'd us to be by confidence
Apply'd Rom. 4. 11, & 24..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: On what dependeth this relation?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Gods promiſe Mar. 16. 16., and his Spirits operation 1 Cor. 12. 13..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How are the Sacraments thing ſignify'd
As ſignes received?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: In whom faith doth abide,
They are partakers of the inward grace,
And Chriſt himſelf (although in heavenly place)
As truely (through the vertue of Gods Sprite)
As of the ſignes objected to the ſight Col. 2. 11, 12, 13. 1 Cor. 5. 7.:
But faithleſſe men, though they receive the ſigne,
Doe not the ſignifi'd things divine compare Act. 8. 13. with 21. 1 Cor. 11 21..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What's Baptiſme?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: 'Tis of our admittance in
To Chriſt his Church 1 Cor. 12. 13.; a Sacrament wherein
By Waters waſhing Mat. 3. 11., in the Trinities,
Fathers, Sons, Spirits, name Mat. 28. 19., God ſignifies,
Seals, and applies to us, our cleanſing by
The blood of Chriſt Rev. 1. 5., from all iniquity 1 Ioh. 1. 7..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What are the ſignes in Baptiſme's Sacrament?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Water is the externall element Mat. 3. 11.:
Dipping in water firſt, or ſprinkling, then
From under it a coming forth agen;
Are the ſubſtantiall rites This is implied Rom. 6. 4..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What's underſtood
By theſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The ſprinkling of our Saviours blood,
To waſh us from our ſinfull filthineſs Rev. 7. 14. Eph. 5. 26. Ezech. 36. 25. Heb. 10. 22.,
And imputation of his righteouſneſs Eph. 5. 27. Gal. 3. 27.;
A killing of the old man, through the force
Of Chriſt his death and buriall, of his courſe Rom. 6. 3, 4, 6. Col. 2. 12.,
A quickning of our ſpirits through the ſtrength
Of Chriſt, his reſurrection Rom. 6. 5., and at length
A raiſing of our bodies 1 Cor. 15. 29., laſt of all,
A ſacred obligation mutuall,
Of God, and us baptized, whereby he
Doth binde himſelf to be our God Act. 2. 38, 39., and we
To ſerve him Mat 3. 8, 11. Rom. 6. 13. & 7. 4., and to fight againſt his foes,
Satan Iames 4. 7., the fleſh Gal. 5. 16, 17. and world, that him oppoſe Iames 4. 4. 1 Iohn 2. 15..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: In Baptiſme what doth water figure moſt
Chiefly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Chriſts bleſſed blood and holy Ghoſt 1 Iohn 5. 6. Iohn 3. 5. Epheſ. 5. 26..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Why doth the water and theſe things agree,
In any manner of analogie?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Yes; for as water helps to generate Pſal. 104. 14.
That it may fructifie doth irrigate
The earth Pſal. 104. 10, 13., doth waſh away the filthineſs
Of bodies 1 Sam. 25. 42. Iohn 13. 5., and doth quench our thirſtineſs Exod. 17. 3..
In manner like, through the moſt wholſome merit
Of Chriſt his blood Heb. 9. 12, 13, 14., and working of his Spirit 1 Iohn 5. 6.,
We are regenerated Iohn 7. 5., waſhed white
From ſin Epheſ. 5. 26. Pſal. 51. 7, (who elſe are filthy in his ſight Pſal. 51. 2, 3.)
And by the ſweeteſt ſhowers of graces drenched Pſal. 72. 6. Hoſ. 9. 3.
Bring forth much fruit Iohn 15. 2, 4, 5. and have our ſouls thirſtPſal. 63. 1. Iſa. 55. 1. quenchedIohn 4. 14..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How is this ſacrament received?

sp.speaker: A
sp.l: All
Who are baptiz'd in manner naturall
Receive the ſignes Act. 2. 41. & 8. 13.; but what they ſignifie Gal. 3. 27. Epheſ. 5. 26.,
As by the Holy Ghoſt ſpiritually
Given 1 Cor. 12. 13. Tit. 3. 5.) they onely who have faith indeed Mar. 16. 16. As thoſe that are of age.,

Or if not faith it ſelf, its heavenly ſeed As in Infants, for to them belongs the Kingdom of God, Mat. 19. 14. and they are within the Covenant of Grace, Act. 2. 39. & 3. 25. and ſome are ſanctified in the womb, as Jeremy and S. John Baptist, and therefore have the ſeeds of faith..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What's the Lord's Supper?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: 'Tis a Sacrament
Of Confirmation 1 Cor. 10. 16, 17., that doth repreſent 1 Cor. 11. 26.,
Commemorate Luke 22. 19., obſignate and apply
Unto the faithfull inſtrumentally 1 Cor. 10. 16, 17.,
(By given and received bread and wine,
(According unto ordinance divine 1 Cor. 11. 23, 24, 25.)
Chriſts body that was ſlain, blood that was ſhed,
By vertue of which body and which blood,
(As of our ſouls onely ſufficient food)
Nouriſht we are Iohn 6. 54, 55, 56., and grow in faith and love Iude ver. 20, 21. Gal 5. 6.,
Till to be perfect men in Chriſt we prove Col. 1. 28, 29. Eph. 4. 13..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the ſigns in the Lords Supper?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Bread
And Wine, the elements adminiſtred 1 Cor. 10. 16.,
The rites are when the Miniſter hath pray'd,
And Chriſt his words of inſtitution ſaid.
And breaks the bread, and doth deliver both
The bread and wine to every one that doth
Come to the Supper, who muſt take both; eat
The bread & drink the wine This whole anſwer is made good by Chriſts own inſtitution of this Sacrament, Mat. 26. 26, 27, 28. Mar. 14. 22, 23, 24. Luke 22. 19, 20..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What are the great
Secrets imported by theſe ſigns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The thing
Whereof theſe are the ſigns exhibiting,
Is Jeſus Chriſt his body and his blood 1 Cor. 10. 16.,
With ev'ry grace of his and ſaving good 1 Cor. 1. 30.,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What mean the Rites?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The breaking of the bread
Doth ſhew how Chriſt was broken, tortured
Upon the Croſſe, and in his agony compare Mat. 26. 26. with Mat. 27. 38, 46. and with Iohn 19. 34.:
The giving of the ſignes, how graciouſly
The Father hath beſtow'd on us his Son,
With all the merits of his paſſion compare Luke 22. 22, 23. with 1 Cor. 10. 16. and with 1 Cor. 1. 30.:
Our taking, eating, drinking, ſhew how we
By faith lay hold on Jeſus Chriſt, and he
Becometh ours ſo truly and indeed,
As doth the very meat whereon we feed compare Mat. 26. 26, 27. with 1 Cor. 12. 27. and with 1 Cor. 10. 16..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: But why was bread ordained as a ſigne
Of Chriſt his body, of his blood, why wine?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: By reaſon of the likeneſſe 'twixt his blood
And wine, his body and that kinde of food 1 Cor. 10. 16, 17..
Bread is the ſtay of our life naturall Mat. 6. 11.,
And ſo is Chriſt of our ſpirituall Iohn 6. 33, 35, 48, 51.;
Bread is our daily food Luke 11. 3., and daily need
Our ſouls on Chriſt their heavenly bread to feed Iohn 6. 53, to 58.;
As many grains one loaf of bread doe make,
And of that one loaf many may partake:
So we, though many, in one bread ſubſiſt,
And of that bread partake, ev'n Jeſus Chriſt 1 Cor. 10. 16, 17..
And as from preſſed grapes doe iſſue wine Deut. 32. 14.,
Which comforteth the heart Iudg. 9. 13. Pſal. 104. 15., ſo from the vine,
Chriſt John 15. 1, 5., by the waight of Gods wrath ſorely preſt Mat. 26. 38, 39. Mat. 27. 46.,
There iſſued his blood, the liquor bleſt Iohn 19. 30, 34.,
That doth as wine, warm, comfort, animate,
Strengthen, revive, delight, exhilerate Iohn 6. 54, 56. Cant. 5. 1..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is the manner that we doe receive
The Supper of the Lord?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: What we perceive
Thereof by ſenſe, the ſame we orally or, with the mouth.
Receive 1 Cor. 11. 26. Mat. 26. 26, 27., but what they ſhew ſpiritually,
(For Chriſt his preſence is not corporall
In the Lords Supper, but ſymbolicall 1 Cor. 10. 16.)
That's onely by our hearts, not hands, imbrac'd,

And is the object of our faith, not taſt Mat. 26. 26, 27. For in thoſe words of inſtitution, our Saviour infolds both the Naturall and Spirituall eating and drinking, wherein conſiſts the true nature of a Sacrament: ſo that the bread and wine are the body and blood of Chriſt ſacramentally, or by a ſacramentall metonymie; and the bread and wine are received by the mouth of the body: and the body and blood of Chriſt by the mouth of the ſoul, viz: by a true and lively faith..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Who then receives this Supper worthily?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: They who repent 1 Cor. 11. 31., have faith 2 Cor. 13. 5. and charity Act. 2. 42, & 4. 32, 34. 1 Cor. 11. 28, 29..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is the end wherefore we celebrate
This Sacrament?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: 'Tis to commemorate
Chriſt, and to ſhew his death by thinking on
Intentively, his bitter paſſion 1 Cor. 11. 26.;
That ſo by thoſe good things we therein ſee 1 Cor. 10. 16.
Our ſouls for ever comforted may be Cant. 5. 1. 2 Cor. 1. 3, 4, 5..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Now you have ſhew'd the means, whereby Chriſt is
Offer'd and apprehended with all his
Merits and benefits, it doth remain,
You ſhew to whom thoſe graces doe pertain.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: They doe belong unto the Church Acts 2. 39, 41., and none
Have intereſt in them, but ſhe alone Rom. 10. 14, 16. Eph. 2. 13. John 8. 24..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is the Church?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: An holy company
Of men elected Col. 3. 12. Eph. 1. 4, 5. Rom. 8. 29., called powerfully 1 Cor. 1. 2. Rom. 1. 7. 1 Tim. 1. 9. Rom. 8. 30.,
From out the world Iohn 17. 6, 9, 16., by preaching of the Word Rom. 10. 17. Epheſ. 1. 12, 13.,
To be the ſole peculiar of the Lord 1 Pet. 2. 9, 10. Tit. 2. 14.:
Built upon Chriſt, Mat. 21. 42. 1 Cor. 3. 9. as on a ſure foundation 1 Cor. 3 10, 11.,
That God in it may have his habitation Iohn 17. 23. Eph. 2. 21, 22.,
And there be ſerv'd in faith Heb. 11. 6., b • prayer expreſt Iames 1. 6.,
And holineſs both inward Epheſ. 1. 4. Col. 1. 22. Epheſ. 4. 23, 24. and profeſt Epheſ. 4, 1, 2, 3. 2 Cor. 7. 1..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How manifold is this Church?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: One 1 Cor. 12. 13. where Chriſt in regard of the ſpirituall union and conjunction is taken for the Church.: though we
That are the members, very many be 1 Cor. 12. 15. & 10. 17. ▪
For as there is one God Eph. 4. 6., faith ver. 5., hope of bliſſe ver. 4.,
Head of the Church Eph. 1. 22. & 4. 13, 5. Col. 1. 18.; ſo conſequently, is
The Church one Eph. 4. 4. & 2. 14, 16., that's the body myſticall 1 Cor. 10. 17.,
Of that head, Jeſus Chriſt the Lord of all Epheſ. 4. 5. Act. 10. 36. Epheſ. 1. 22..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: If that the Church be one, in what ſenſe doe
We ſay, ſhe may be ſeen, and may not too?

div.head: 20. Concerning the Church viſible and inviſible.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The whole Church Catholick Iſa. 2. 2, 3. Act. 10. 34, 35., Chriſts body Eph. 1. 23. Col. 1. 18., houſe 1 Tim. 3. 15.,
The Templ • of the Lord Epheſ. 1. 21., his City Heb. 12. 22. Revel. 21. 10. Epheſ. 2. 19., Spouſe Cant. 4. 9, to 12.,
Cannot be ſeen, becauſe it doth contain
The number of all them that doe pertain
To Chriſt, as well the bleſſed ſaints on high,
Who cannot be beheld with mortall eye Heb. 12. 22.;
As faithfull living Iohn 10. 16. & 11. 52.: though particular
Churches or Congregations, which are
But ſome part of that Church, apparent be,
Becauſe we doe the outward faſhion ſee,
Of their religion 1 Cor. 1. 2. & 2 Cor. 1. 1. Gal. 2. Rom 16. 5. Col. 4. 15..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: The whole Church, why
Doe you call Catholick?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: To ſignifie
She is not ty'de to certain times, or men,
Nor places, (as before Chriſts coming, when
God was in Jury onely worſhipped Pſal. 76. 1, 2. Iſa. 2. 3.)
But is throughout the whole world ſcattered Acts 10. 33, 34, 35. 1 Theſ. 1. 8.:
And is ſtill to indure Luke 1. 33., and hath among
All kindes of men, ſome that to her belong Iſa. 60, the whole chap..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Who are theſe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Not who onely doe profeſſe
Faith, and have but the Form of Godlineſſe 2 Tim. 3. 8.:
For albeit ſuch kinde of men have place
In the Church viſible Act▪ 8. 13., yet to the grace
Of being members I mean true members of the Church. of the ſame, attain
They do not 1 Iohn 2. 19. Iohn 15. 6. 2 Tim. 4. 10. Act. 8. 21. Mat. 22. 14.; but thoſe in whom grace doth raign Tit. 2. 11, 12. 1 Pet. 1. 5.:
For Chriſt his Church is holy Eph. 1. 4, 5., 'cauſe his blood
Hath cleanſed her from ſin Eph. 1. 7., to doe what's good as ver. 3, 4..

div.head: 21. Who is head of the Church.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Who of the Churches body is the head?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Chriſt Jeſus Col. 1. 18. Epheſ. 1. 12..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: Who beſides in Chriſt his ſtead?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: None other, for 'tis monſtrouſly unfit
One body ſhould to many heads be knit Epheſ. 5. 23, 30. this Text proves it as unfit as for a woman to have many husbands.:
And what need there any head leſſe principall,
To guide and rule the Church, ſith there dwells all
Fulneſſe in Chriſt Coloſ. 2. 3, 9. Iſa 9. 6, 7.: and as the head doth ſenſe
Unto the body, ſo Chriſt influence
Spirituall, unto the Church conveyes Col. 2. 10, 11, 12.,
And every where is with her, and alwaies Matth. chap. 28. ver. 20. Iohn 14. 16, 18..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But may there not be ſome to overſee
Churches particular? Is't ſo that he,
Becauſe he doth the whole Church regulate;
Excludeth governours ſubordinate
Of Churches viſible?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: No each ſuch, muſt
Have one, or many, who not as they luſt 1 Pet. 5. 3.
But as Gods Word alloweth them, muſt guide,
Govern, defend it ſafely, and provide
That God be purely ſerv'd, that they be curb'd,

By whom the Churches peace may be diſturb'd; And this hath reſpect as well to the Civil Power as to Eccleſiaſticall Authority, and to both in their ſeverall ſtations, and it belongs to the Civil Power; firſt for the defence of the Church, as Judges 2. 16. and ſecondly, becauſe without that, true Religion cannot long ſtand, as Judg. 17. 6. 1 Chro. 14. 3. 1 Kings 10. 9. and therefore when God at any time doth favourably look upon a nation, he doth ſtill raiſe up ſuch guiders, governours and defenders of them, and providers for his pure ſervice, and ſuch as may curb the enemies of his Church; ſuch were Moſes, Joſua, David, Salomon, Jehoſhaphat, Joſias, Hezekias, Conſtantine the great, with many other Chriſtian Princes.
That all things be in decent order done 1 Cor. 14. 40. 1 Cor. 11. 34. Eph. 4. 11, 1 • .,

And who offends may have correction 1 Tim. 1. 20. Now to ſee that all things be done in the Church, in ſuch decent order, and that thoſe may be puniſhed, that by obſtinate reſiſtance, or ſcandalous living, ſhall tranſgreſſe againſt it; this ſolely belongs to Eccleſiaſticall Authoritie, as by theſe enſuing places may be proved. 1 Pet. 5 2, 3. 1 Tim. 5. 7. 17, 19, 20 Act. 20. 17. Heb. 13. 7. 17. Mat. 16. 19. John 20. 23. 1 Cor. 5. 2 Theſ. 3. 6. and 12, 14, 15. Mat. 18. 15, 16, 17, 18. Tit. 3. 10..

div.head: 22. The deſcription of a true Church.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: But tell me, by what markes infallible,
We may diſcerne a true Church viſible
From a corrupt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: In that Church where Gods Word
Is purely taught John 8. 31, 32. and 10. 27. Act. 2. 42. 2 Ep. John. 9., the Supper of the Lord,
And Baptiſme, miniſter'd in manner due,
After Chriſts Ordinances, that Church is true Math. 28. 19. Act. 2. 38. Luke 22. 19, 20. Act. 2. 42..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Is every man when he thoſe marks hath found
In any Congregation, there bound
To joyne himſelfe unto it, and profeſſe
Himſelfe a Member of it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Surely yes,
To ſome ſuch Church or other, every man
Muſt joyne himſelfe, ſo far forth as he can Act. 2. 47. Pſal. 133. the whole.:
For every ſuch Church is a School, where God
The Maſter is Iſa. 54. 13. Mat. 23. 8., afflictions his rod Pſal. 119. 71.;
The Teſtaments the Books which there are read,
The Law, and Goſpell, there delivered Gal. 4. 24.,
With Preachers expoſition explain'd Rom. 10. 14, 15.,
Leſſons that muſt be learned, and retain'd
In minde and heart Pſal. 119. 1, 2, 7, 10, 11.: now in the Schools muſt he,
As a young Scholer educated be Pſal. 119. 9. Deut. 11. 18, 19.,
That doth aſpire unto a place on high,
In the moſt glorious Univerſity Eph. 2. 6. Mat. 25. 34..

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What Ʋniverſity?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Even that ſame where The Saints are Fellowes, who were Schollers here: The Angells Fellowes, in the joynt fruition Of joyes, ariſing from Gods bliſſefull Viſion 1 John 1. 3, 4. Heb. 12. 22, 23, 24.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What joyes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: eye hath ſeen, Nor heard by mortall eares have ever been;
Neither, what great joyes they are, it enter can
Into the Sinfull heart of Carnall man 1 Cor. 2. 9..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: What is this Viſion whence you ſay ariſe
Theſe joyes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It is to know God in ſuch wiſe
As we our ſelves are knowne; to have that grace
As to behold him cleerly face to face 1 Cor. 9. 10, 12..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: And why call you it bliſſefull?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Cauſe hereon
Depend there doth our glorification Pſal. 16. 11. Phil. 3. 21. Heb. 12. 22, 23..
For ſeeing him Pſ. 73. 25. and 142. 5. and 33. 12., him we ſhall have, and have
In him, all good things, that our Souls can crave 1 Cor. 15. 28. Rom. 8. 32.;
And we ſhall be transformed into his
Image, ſo fa • re forth, as our nature is
Made capable thereof 2 Cor. 3. 18. 1 John 3. 2., and ſhine as light,
Our Souls and Bodies ſhall in glorie bright Compare 1 Joh. 1. 5. and John 1. 4, 5, 9. with Joh. 6. 56. and 1 John 3. 24..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: For ever 1 Theſ. 4. 17. Pſal. 90. 2.: for our bliſſe (as he
That is its object x) ſhall eternall be 1 Pet. 5. 10. Luk. 18. 30..

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: But to be happy in ſuch ſort, you ſay
Belongs not unto all men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: True: for they
Who are not Souldiers in the Church, that here
Is Militant, may not as Victors weare
Crownes, in the Church triumphant 2 Tim. 4. 7, 8. Jam. 1. 12. Revel. 2. 20. 1 Pet. 5. 4.; not behold
Chriſts glory, that are not of Chriſts Fold Compare John 10. 16. ver. with 26, 27, 28. ver. .

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: How ſhall it then be with the wicked?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: All
Shall ſuffer puniſhment perpetuall Jud. 14, 15. 2 Theſ. 1. 7, 8, 9.,
According to their workes Rom. 2. 5, 6. Luk. 12. 47, 48., for Chriſt ſhall come
To judge the world 2 Cor. 5, 10. Act. 10. 42. Act. 17. 31. 2 Tim. 4. 1 Joh. 5. 22., and having placed ſome
On his Right hand Mat. 25. 33, 34., I meane the Sons of light Iohn 12. 36.;
Thus, he will them moſt graciouſly invite:
Come bleſſed of my Father, and inherit
The glorious Kingdome Mat. 25. 34., purchas'd by my merit 1 Pet. 1. 18, 19. Eph. 1. 7.,
Prepared from eternity, for you Mat. 25. 34.
My conſtant followers and ſervants true Mat. 19. 28, 29..
But to the wicked that ſhall trembling ſtand Deut. 28. 65. Mat. 24. 26.,
With guilty Conſciences Io. 8. 9. Ro. 2. 15., at his left hand;
In terrifying manner, he will ſay,
Ye curſed wofull wretches, get away
Into eternall fire, prepar'd for you,
As for the Devill, and his damned crue Mat. 25. 41.;
And thoſe ſhall ſtill tormented be in Hell,
When they for ever ſhall in Heaven dwell Dan. 12. 2. Iohn 5. 29. Mat. 25. 46..

lg.l: WHat good is taught us here, Lord do thou make
Us perfectly to know, for Chriſt his ſake;
And let that knowledge, ſo informe our minde,
That through it, in our hearts we be inclin'd,
To doe that good ſincerely though we may
Offend in many things through weakneſſe • ſay
O gratious God, the Word, and it will then
Be done, what we pray for, Amen, Amen.
